Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: 2024 VCE Geography external assessment report

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: In the 2024 Geography examination, many students attempted the whole paper, with few questions left unanswered. Students were able to demonstrate sound geographic knowledge, with some providing well above standard responses throughout the examination.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Responses generally showed a good level of geographic competency with appropriate use of geography-specific terminology. Most students utilised up-to-date case studies and statistics. Lower-scoring responses indicated generalisations, which were, at times, also out of date.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students should exercise discernment in selecting the most appropriate case study and data to use to respond to questions. Higher-scoring responses used data that added to the depth of their response; lower-scoring responses used data indiscriminately. The application of relevant data in a strategic way is a focus area for guiding students into higher achievement. Responses that included all the numbers that had been learnt indicated an inability to discern what the question is asking. In general, however, the case studies used by students in written responses were appropriate and on-topic. There was a significant reliance on textbook knowledge evident across all areas of assessment. This was particularly evident with the use of Greenland as a case study for Land Cover Change and either Bangladesh or Niger as the population case study for a growing population.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: There were a significant number of responses that were off-topic or demonstrated inadequate preparation, particularly in Questions 3 and 9, the two longer 10-mark questions. The use of the formulaic 'Pattern, Quantity and Exception' for Question 6 was not required and impacted negatively in some responses. Rigid application of this formula did not support focus on the changes between the two timeframes as the question required. Rote learning of responses, as was evident in some responses to Question 9 in particular, is not encouraged, as it does not support students to address the focus of questions asked in this examination. The application of key skills and key knowledge continues to be the focus of the examination.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students should ensure they understand the command/instructional terms. Of note in the 2024 examination, questions that directed students to 'analyse' or describe 'to what extent' required they make a determination of assessment, level of agreement or accuracy and explain this further in their response. The explanation as to the accuracy of their determination was the most important part of the response. This permitted a variation of finite decisions that could be made by students. Responses could either agree or disagree with a statement; it was the geographic reasoning that was being fully marked. Answers should have included underlying analysis, such as positive/negative, social/economic or short-/long-term understandings. It was not possible to fully respond to such questions without first making a determination and then supporting/analysing.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: In the Answer Book, lines are included beneath each question as an indication of the depth or length of the expected response; these do not account for variation in handwriting. Students are permitted - and encouraged - to use the extra writing space provided at the end of the Answer Book, if required. Students are to alert assessors should extra writing space be utilised in their responses. This was done well in 2024 by the majority of students. With more writing space included in the Answer Book this year, fewer students required supplementary booklets to complete their written responses.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Note: Student responses reproduced in this report have not been corrected for grammar, spelling or factual information.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: This report provides sample answers or an indication of what answers may have included. Unless otherwise stated, these are not intended to be exemplary or complete responses.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The statistics in this report may be subject to rounding resulting in a total more or less than 100 per cent.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent:
Note: Student responses reproduced in this report have not been corrected for grammar, spelling or 
factual information.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: This report provides sample answers or an indication of what answers may have included. Unless otherwise stated, these are not intended to be exemplary or complete responses

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The statistics in this report may be subject to rounding, resulting in a total of more or less than 100 per cent.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students were asked to identify and describe a natural characteristic of a forest.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Most students were able to answer this question, but in general more detail was needed to receive full marks. Some responses showed a lack of understanding of the term 'natural characteristic', and students are reminded to focus as thoroughly on physical geography as on human geography.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Identification may be embedded in the description or made as a separate statement. A description is not an explanation. Description may include appearance, function, spatial arrangement or interconnection, and can include specialised terminology such as 'canopy' or 'understorey'.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent:
One natural characteristic of forests are closed forests. Closed forests consist of tall sun reaching trees that create a dense canopy, often shielding the forest floor from obtaining much sunlight. These are mostly consisted of rainforests, which are approx. 40% of earths forests, making closed forests 
quite expansive.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Environmental impacts could include:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: damage to water table, loss of habitat, irreparable loss of biodiversity, extinction of species, loss of soil nutrition

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: location-specific impacts (e.g. identifying a specific plant being impacted or specifying the damage at this location; reduced impact of forest fires due to selective logging at this location)

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: intensifying effects of climate change; hotter and drier with less forest cover.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Social conditions would be location-specific and could include:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: positive - locations for housing being provided or jobs for the local population

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent:
negative - loss of cultural connection or hunting/spiritual connections, or deaths of local people who stand in the way of progress; migration of non-locals into the area further impacting 
cultural losses.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response for Cameroon:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Environment: in the process of cutting down trees (deforestation) this releases harmful gases into the atmosphere, especially CO2 emissions which accelerate the greenhouse gas effect assisting with climate change with Cameroon producing around 110 million metric tons of CO2 emissions due to deforestation.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Social conditions: An impact on social conditions is the impact on communities that live near areas that have experienced deforestation which depletes natural resources that are of use to them and the connection they shared with the land that may now be lost, hindering connections to sacred land.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to discuss one issue and associated challenge of the impact on the social conditions outlined in part a.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students needed to write about a social condition linked to the impact of deforestation at this location. These impacts may include people needing to migrate, animals or vegetation requiring protection, funding needed to address the social condition identified, and change in structures due to new working arrivals.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The challenges that arise to respond to this issue would be linked to deforestation. These could include the need to address the economic pressure to continue deforestation, government corruption in illegal logging practices, raising social awareness of the negative consequences of deforestation, legislation and enforcement of means to protect local/traditional norms from changes.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: A reminder of these terms:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: an issue or issues may result from deforestation

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent:
a challenge is what needs to be responded to by governments, non-government organisations 
or individuals.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response for Borneo:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: A major issue arising from the loss of livelihood security is the loss of secure land rights for indigenous communities. Although many communities rely on forests for cultural identity and forest resources, ~40% of Indigenous land claims in Borneo are legally recognised. The associated challenge is that plantation concessions frequently overlap with customary land with over 55% of new concessions since the 2010s have been granted on indigenous territories. This makes it extremely difficult for communities to contest land grabs or seek compensation, leading to ongoing poverty with rates reaching up to 30% in forest fringe areas and loss of cultural practices and a continued conflict with palm oil companies.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Responses covered a wide range of case studies including Borneo, Cameroon, the Amazon, Sumatra, PNG, Central Victoria, Tanzania, Tasmania, the Philippines, Madagascar and Ghana. Students demonstrated a good knowledge of their case study for deforestation and an understanding of environmental and social impacts. Many students used case-study-specific data to support their discussion, such as the number of gorillas or orangutans left in the wild, or the specifics of the Baku people. There was an evident and clear understanding from many students about the difference between an issue and a challenge. Higher-scoring responses were awarded marks according to their choice of issue and data relating to the challenge. Students are encouraged to use time-management skills to answer the question; general context for the case study was not required.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to use grassland and coniferous forest data to show there are both similarities and differences in the locations across the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. Accurate and relevant quantification would lift the quality of the answers.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Overall, this question was well done, and most students were able to describe the data effectively. However, some did not focus on comparison and some did not incorporate data into their responses.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Both the distribution of grassland and coniferous forest is located predominantly in the northern hemisphere evident as grassland is distributed from 90-5N latitude and only slightly in the southern hemisphere from 0-45S latitude. This is similar to coniferous forests, distributed from 80-5N latitude and only slightly in the southern hemisphere from 0-50S latitude. However grassland covers a significantly larger area of vegetation compared to coniferous forests. This is evident as grassland reaches a distribution of 340 km2 at 50-45N compared to coniferous forests which reaches a maximum of 75 km2 at 40-35N.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: This question tested students' understanding of the nature of a glacier and their ability to read a map.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: East and east-south-east were accepted responses, with the most common error being south-east.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Responses were required to provide the length of the glacier for the years 1890 and 2010. Units of measurement needed to be included.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The most common error was an incorrect response for 2010. A misunderstanding of the process of glacier melting was evident when it was misinterpreted that the glacier had melted and retreated in a location other than the terminus/snout.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to distinguish between a glacier and an ice sheet. Specific examples could be used to support the identified differences, which demonstrated a general understanding of what a glacier is as part of the evaluation. Many responses did not differentiate an ice sheet from sea ice.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: A glacier is ice that forms on the tops of mountains through the accumulation of snow each year with the snow that doesn't melt settling hard forming a glacier (and contains rocks). However an ice sheet forms flat and generally stretches for long distance. The main difference is that glaciers are on mountains where ice sheets are not.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to identify their case study and give enough detail to establish that melting of ice sheets and glaciers is occurring at this location. The geospatial technology being used is an assessment tool and should be clearly identified, with its use at this location explained. The management of the ice sheet / glacier needed to be linked to the information received from the geospatial technology.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent:
Most schools are continuing to use Greenland as an example. Other locations included Chile, Kyrgyzstan, Alaska, Peru, Norway, Pakistan, the Andes, New Zealand, Bhutan, the Himalayas / Nepal and Switzerland. Students had a strong understanding of what geospatial technologies are, but needed to use data to help support their evaluation. Some students presented pre-written responses, which did not adequately address the question and therefore were unable to achieve full marks. Higher-scoring responses successfully distinguished between 'assessing' and 'managing', and applied these concepts to data for their 
selected location.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: In Ilulissat, Greenland, the two GRACE Satellites have to some extent assisted in effectively assessing and managing rates of melting glaciers and ice sheets (MGIS) nationally. This project involved the initial construction of the first GRACE satellite in 2017 and the consequent second satellite being constructed in May 2018. These satellites hover over 500 km above ground level and can provide precise data on the recent melting of Greenland's MGIS. These satellites utilise the volume and density of the air in order to explicitly collect data on where MGIS is occurring and to what extent they are melting. The satellites collected data on one of Greenland's biggest glaciers, the Jakobshaven glacier, where in 2019 600 billion tonnes of ice melted contributing to approximately a 0.8mm sea level rise. The satellites have also calculated that overall 27 gigatons of ice have melted within Greenland, which could cause sea levels to rise by up to 2.2mm approximately. Furthermore, the satellites are an extremely efficient way for the Greenland and surrounding governments such as the Danish government to assess rates of MGIS through explicit understanding of where MGIS is occurring within Greenland and by how much. This can lead to effective management by government as data collected by the satellites have raised awareness for the implementation and severity revolved around the MGIS in Greenland. In response the Greenland government has implemented responses such as the Hydropower Plant Project in order to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from diesel powered electricity and instead increase the usage of green, sustainable and clean energy in the town of Ilulissat, Greenland. Contributing to lowered carbon dioxide emissions which can lower the enhanced greenhouse effect, in an attempt to restrict MGIS from occurring. These satellites are financially sustainable due to the fact that as much as they were expensive to implement (costing up to $270million US), data collected has driven awareness within Greenland for MGIS, contributing to socially sustainable responses being made by governments and citizens. Overall the long term positives of the satellites outweigh the initial high set up costs, and other potential restrictions such as satellite inability to functions adequately during extreme weather events. Evidently showing that this geo-spatial technology has done more than "little" to effectively assess and managed MGIS in Greenland and is overall quite an effective response.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students needed to identify change from 'x' land use to 'y' land use at this location.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Strong fieldwork knowledge was evident for most students.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Geographic characteristics can be human or natural, though students were not required to identify these with this terminology. Two geographic characteristics - such as location, scale, topography, regional setting, infrastructure of the site or demographic characteristics - needed to be identified. Possible responses could include proximity to other local features making it ideal to develop (e.g. near a train station so greater access for patrons/residents) or demand in the local area (e.g. no other primary school around and there is a population bulge in this age group). Students needed to identify how each of these characteristics resulted in this location being changed from one land use to the next. Students could use two natural geographic characteristics, two human characteristics or a combination of both. Characteristics needed to be explained, not just elaborated with description. Students needed to explain how the characteristic impacted the land use change. For example, the site was sufficiently large (= scale).

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Many students explained the impacts of the change at their fieldwork site used for part a. This is a different question, and students could not be awarded for marks for this response. A significant number of students explained economic or social drivers of the change instead of geographic characteristics. Overall, this fieldwork section as part of the Land Use Change area of study was well done.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Hawthorn Grove Estate's land use moved from commercial to residential from 1960-2014, the land was used as "Hotel California" (commercial). Following this, the land was cleared and from 2014-2024 the land became residential.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: A geographic characteristic that likely impacted the land use change of the Hawthorn Grove Estate is the human geographic characteristic of close proximity to schools. The Hawthorn Grove Estate is directly opposite the school Xavier College, 400 metres from MLC and 1km from Glenferrie Primary School. This makes the location a desirable spot for families to live, influencing the change from commercial to residential. Another human geographic characteristic that likely influenced the land use change of the Hawthorn Grove Estate is its close proximity to the city. The land is approximately 6km East of Melbourne's CBD, which make the location a desirable spot for home buyers. This is because, being so close to the CBD means transport is more accessible and is closer to a wider array of services, such as food and hospitality.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to describe three types of population movement using different origin and destination examples, with a brief statement of why each type of population movement is occurring between the origin and destination given. For example, people are migrating from Tuvalu to New Zealand as forced migration. With the sea level rising surrounding Tuvalu, people have no choice but to relocate and New Zealand's society and government has welcomed a limited number of these forced environmental refugees.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Forced migration is an example of low agency migration, where people often have no choice but to migrate. An example of migration from the country of origin Ukraine to the country of destination Poland. Following the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022, many Ukrainians were forced to seek refuge in Poland due to their close proximity and Poland's swift humanitarian response. As of May 2025, 1 million Ukrainian refugees are living in Poland, but up to 5 million resided in Poland at some point throughout the invasion.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Voluntary migration is an example of high agency migration, where the individual migrates due to their choice. An example is migration from India (country of Origin) to the UAE (country of destination). This movement is often due to economic migration where people from India seek work in the UAE. As of 2023, there are 3.5 million Indian labour migrants in the UAE, and blue-collar jobs have increased by 25%.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Long-term migration can either be high or low agency, and involves the individual migrating for extended period of time. An example is to move permanently from Australia (country of origin) to Japan (country of destination). In Tokyo, 3% of their population in their 20s is made up of migrants from Australia.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students were able to earn up to 3 of the 4 marks per migration type, but struggled to get the fourth mark because they did not give a detailed enough example in the discussion. A strength of this question saw students utilise three different migration examples. Higher-scoring responses included a clear example with data/numbers and linked to reasons, and factoring in push/pull, choice/agency and so on. Many were able to use an example of origin and destination from their case study for aging or growing populations. Students who got full marks for each type showed a deep understanding of the movement type.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to use the population structure provided to identify that there are more people of working age than there are of economic dependence.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Dependent population - both youth dependents and old age dependents are significantly smaller in number than economically active population.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Country A is experiencing a Demographic Dividend as there is a large number of 16-65 year old people which are able to work. There is a large bump in population among middle aged which can be seen by 4.7% male and 4.6% females in the 30-34 section.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students needed to correctly identify that this population structure will age into the future and the smaller number of people shown under the current working age will result in a significantly impacted/reversed demographic dividend in the future. There will be an aged population and this will require government and NGO planning now to ease the impact and provide sustainability into the next 30 to 40 years. Students were required to make a prediction using data from the figure.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: In the next 30-40 years, 80% of Country A's current working population will be in or nearing retirement, resulting in a larger dependency population that the government will have to account for. Country A also shows low birth rates in 2025, being only 6% of pop is 0-4, this means that in 30-40 years, the work force will not be large enough to account for the aged/retired pop resulting in a deficit of workers to look after the elderly. Thus, the challenge would be a demographic deficit as elderlys are more prevalent and DTM 4 indicate a reducing birth rate.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: This question was well answered and most students used data from the population pyramid. The expression 'justify using evidence' means to use the data provided. Some students were unable to predict a challenge, but those students who did were able to justify and use data in support of their prediction.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students were required to identify the nature of population trends. The rate of growth may be continuing or be impacted by government and NGO plans and policies. This is evident as the country is moving through the population structures that are typical of the Demographic Transition Model stages. A variety of sketches would be considered acceptable. The validity of these sketches is the core factor. Examples of sketch diagrams could include age gender structures or positions on the DTM.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response for Tanzania:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Tanzania is experiencing a rapidly growing population, evident by a growth rate of 2.9%, however over time, Tanzania's structure has changed considerably.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: During 1990s, Tanzania had a high fertility rate of 5.03 and high growth rate of 3.05%. This resulted in a large youthful population, as seen in figure c, and a small elderly population thus placing Tanzania in stage 2 of the Demographic Transition Model (DTM), as seen in figure B. This can be attributed to low female literacy rates at 48% leading to low education surrounding contraception and therefore high fertility rates, evident as 40% of girls aged 15-19 with no education had a child, compared to 6% of those with secondary education. This can also be attributed to high levels of poverty, with 26.4% below the poverty line, leading to high levels of subsistence agriculture and kids seen as an economic asset, leading to high fertility.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: During 2025, both the fertility rate and growth rate have decreased significantly, at 4.5 and 2.9% respectively. This has resulted in a smaller, youthful population, although still large with 42% below 15 and a larger elderly population placing Tanzania in late stage 2/early stage 3 of the DTM as seen in figure B. This can be attributed to decreasing infant mortality rates, at 57/1000 live births reducing the need for replacement children as well as increased contraception rising from 27% in 2017 to 31.7% in 2025 and unmet need for contraception decreasing from 50% in 2017 to 22% in 2025.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: As Tanzanians general population trend is a decreasing fertility rate and increasing life expectancy, Tanzania is likely to enter a demographic dividend in the future as seen by the population structure in figure D. This is because lower fertility rates mean there is a smaller proportion of youthful dependents to care for. However high fertility rates in the past means there is a large working class, thus resulting in economic growth for the country.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students sketched a wide range of diagrams, including population structure diagrams, maps of the country and population over time. Students were generally able to discuss what was currently happening with the population but some did not analyse the change over time or how the change may impact the country into the future. Some students used a prepared response that did not answer the question, and therefore did not enable them to achieve marks. Some students drew detailed sketches but did not refer to them or annotate them, so it was not clear what the diagrams were showing. A wide range of countries were chosen, including Chad, Kenya, Tanzania, South Sudan, Saudi Arabia and Madagascar, with the majority of students choosing either Bangladesh or Niger.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Two separate issues of the demographic needed to be named. These could have included a negative pressure caused by this population type or a positive influence or impact upon the society.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students needed to link this answer to their answer for part a. The strategy selected needed to be named and its main aims given.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students needed to discuss the strategy identified in part b. Outcomes of this strategy were to be clearly identified as being positive or negative to resolve the demographic issue being faced at this location. Students were required to use evidence to support the discussion on environmental, social, economic and cultural impacts, as the question asked for an evaluation of the strategy.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The following is an example of a high-scoring response for Germany:

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The response implemented by BMW has seen a high level of effectiveness in targeting the declining working age sector. They implement over 70 amendments, which totalled just $64,000 euros, thus denoting the economically viable outcomes. These amendments included the introduction of weight adapted footwear and wooden floors which reduce the knee pain and strain on their workers, thus removing the potentiality of retirement through injury. Further, they introduced more frequent workstation changes as well as "barber style" work chairs, which reduces strain on one part of the body within an entire days work, as well as ensuring adequate and sufficient rest within breaks. Their success has been outlined through quantifiable evidence, whereby in 2020 50% of Dinggolfingsc (town in Germany) workers were above the age of 50. Alongside this, their review of the strategy has seen a 5% reduction in absenteeism and an increase in productivity by 7%. Through conducted surveys, it was outlined that this is likely due to their enjoyment in work and great fullness towards the ability to keep working through old age. This highlights the effectiveness as it reduces the pressure among the government agencies and the pension system, as more individuals remain paying taxes. As the way Germany's current pension system works is the money is immediately collected and distributed among retirees. As a result, 85% of the pensioners income is state financed, which pressures the government seeing an additional $154billion required in 2021 to meet the owed incomes. Thus the BMW response is actively reducing these perceived issues. However, it is not a long term response as eventually total fertility rates must be targeted and advanced. Overall, the BMW response targets the reduced working age sector and reduces pressure on the German government.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students needed to use reading time to plan this response as all three parts of this question were linked. Information provided in part a. needed to allow students to respond to the next two parts of Question 10. High-scoring responses were able to link the students' strategies directly to the issue and to the idea of an ageing population.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Students worked on a wide range of case studies: Australia, Japan and Germany were some of the most popular, and Italy, Spain, China, Portugal, Romania, Finland, South Korea and Singapore were also included.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: The strategy for Germany was often open-door policy, but this was too vague and inaccurate. Responses for Germany also referred to examples used by populist politicians rather than data, particularly around unemployment, racism, crime, etc. Japanese examples use Angel Plan, Abenomics and robots, but these were often superficial. Students should choose a country with sufficient current and accurate policies/data. Many of the strategies implemented are now over 20 years old, which allows for evaluation but not many current approaches.

Subject: Geography
SectionHeaderContent: Generally, students should use the reading time to read over the questions and determine the structure and complexity required for the long-response questions. They should look for multi-part questions to ensure it is possible to respond to all parts with a linking response. Students should be very careful not to contradict themselves (i.e. in responses for questions 2a/2b and 10a/10b). Students would benefit from taking a moment to plan their long-answer responses, so they do not repeat themselves too much and effectively use the writing space provided with specifics. In this examination, students were able to show that they knew their case studies and had data to support their statements.
